values.alignmentText: In China, .NET roles exist with steady openings in Shanghai/Beijing; sponsorship varies, but big metros offer competitive pay and some remote options.
China's 2D Environmental Artist pay trails top markets by ~25–30%. Strong studios and city living balance this for families in Shanghai/Beijing.
China's major cities (Beijing, Shanghai) offer sporadic bootcamps. Most 2D environmental art training is online.
China hosts several strong art/animation programs (CAFA, CUC) that regularly supply 2D environment artists to local game studios.
China has a large local talent pool for 2D environmental artists, speeding hiring. Most searches close in 1-2 months, aligning with global benchmarks.
CN's 2D environmental art scene is mostly Mandarin; English talent exists mainly in multinationals, with indie studios leaning Mandarin.
China: remote/hybrid 2D environmental art roles exist, but many studios favor periodic onsite collaboration; maturity varies by studio.
CN has a large 2D environment art pool with studios in Shanghai/Beijing. Senior talent is competitive but accessible via remote hiring.
China's 3D animator pay trails top markets by ~25-30%. Expat packages and Shanghai/Beijing studios offer growth with lower living costs.
China's major cities offer regular 3D animation courses and workshops; universities and studios provide bilingual options and online learning.
China hosts several strong 3D animation degree programs (Beijing/Shanghai). These programs consistently feed local studios with job-ready graduates.
China's 3D animator roles typically fill in 1–2 months in hubs like Shanghai due to large talent pools. For foreign hires, visa time can extend the process.
China (Beijing/Shanghai): Mandarin dominates; English-capable 3D animators mainly in multinationals; indie studios lean toward Chinese.
China: remote 3D animator roles exist case-by-case; studios mostly favor on-site collaboration, with remote options limited to project needs.
China's 3D animator pool is robust across Shanghai and Beijing, with many mid-senior talents and recent shipped projects; hiring remains competitive.
China: 3D character artist pay trails top markets by ~25-30%; cost of living and local benefits in hubs like Shanghai/Beijing offset it.
China offers sporadic 3D character art training; most learning is online or via visiting experts, with limited in-person programs in Beijing/Shanghai.
China has several strong 3D/CG programs (CAFA and others) producing industry-ready grads annually. This yields a robust local pipeline for 3D character artists.
China has a large local pool for 3D character artists. Typical local hires take 1-2 months, while expat recruitment may be longer.
In CN, 3D character artists rely on Mandarin; English proficiency is common mainly in multinational studios; expect bilingual hiring or translation support.
Remote 3D character artist roles in China exist case-by-case; studios expect onsite collaboration and limited process maturity.
China's 3D character artist landscape is large, with hundreds of specialists across Tencent/NetEase and outsourcing partners. It shows a robust mix of senior and mid-level talent.
China has game accelerators in major hubs Beijing, Shenzhen; annual cohorts exist, but foreign entrants often need a local entity and Chinese-language support.
China's Tier 1 cities face frequent PM2.5 spikes; outdoor play risky for kids on smog days. Use home filtration and sealable windows when air quality worsens.
China has major anchors (Tencent/NetEase) and many studios; solid game dev ecosystem with grants, but visas and language/policy hurdles apply.
In China, atheism is state-supported and common. Public religious activity is restricted, while everyday life remains secular.
China's single-party rule with surveillance and censorship heightens backsliding risk. Civil liberties remain tightly restricted.
CN banking is mobile-payments driven (WeChat/Alipay) in practice. Foreigners often face longer account-opening processes and forex-transfer limits.
China's beaches exist, but water quality and crowding reduce family appeal; visits near Shanghai or Qingdao can be stressful.
CN's urban hubs (Shanghai, Beijing) have family-friendly boardgame cafes and clubs. Outside these cities, groups are sparse and coordination helps.
China: thinness often emphasized in schools and workplaces; watch diet talk and nurture inclusive, healthy attitudes for the kids and family.
In China, major tech hubs have solid cloud/web demand, but policy swings can hit segments; keep funds ready and diversify skills.
China cancer incidence rising; industrial pollution and urban hubs create risk pockets; access to specialized care varies by region.
China's carceral system shows reports of abuse and forced labor; serious human rights concerns affect family safety and immigration prospects.
In China, public nurseries exist but waitlists and costs push families to private centers or grandparents; networking helps access reliable care.
China's cities offer parks and schools, but traffic and language gaps can hamper family life. Amenities vary by district.
In China, some cities offer childcare stipends and longer maternity leave, but benefits are patchy and hukou-tied; foreigners pay more.
In China, visa families are largely excluded from public childcare subsidies; expect private care or expatriate options for the kids.
Mahjong and karaoke (KTV) are mainstream in urban China; mobile gaming is ubiquitous. Board/tabletop cafés are growing, matching the family's gaming interests.
CN hosts active game/dev communities in Beijing/Shanghai; expect monthly meetups and annual conferences, though English access varies.
CN urban areas offer wellness programs and preventive care messaging, but families often rely on expat/local parent groups to stay motivated.
In China, organized community living is scarce. Stable, family-friendly options are limited to niche expat or pilot co-housing projects.
China CM compensation trails top markets by ~25-30%, with Shanghai/Beijing offering higher pay; lower cost of living can offset.
China has sporadic community manager trainings with occasional workshops in Beijing and Shanghai. Most learning is online or self-directed.
China has marketing and digital media programs; dedicated community manager curricula are limited. Studios partner with schools for internships to fill the gap.
China offers a large pool of bilingual CN professionals; expect 2-3 months to hire a community manager in major cities with local networks.
China (CN): English CM usage exists but local language dominates; prioritize bilingual candidates or plan translation/onboarding support.
In China, studios favor partial remote weeks with on-site work; remote options exist case-by-case, aligning with the family's hybrid needs.
China offers a solid CM pool in Beijing/Shanghai with mid- and senior talent; seniors are competitive, but local and outsourcing options exist.
In China, expat circles in major cities are friendly but locals stay reserved; social ties develop via schools and clubs.
China established studios usually align with global medians after cost of living; prioritize housing and schooling subsidies, plus visa support for families.
China Tier-1 startup comps trail top hubs but offer equity; cash near global medians after cost of living adjustments; push for family-friendly terms.
CN's strict police registrations, minors' exit permits, and Great Firewall controls create a volatile visa path; policy shifts can jeopardize status quickly.
China has regular coding bootcamps and university extensions in megacities; many programs are Chinese-language, with some English options.
China has a large IT contractor pool in Beijing/Shanghai/Shenzhen. For foreign clients, onboarding can take weeks due to local contracts and language.
In China, strict drug laws and heavy policing limit civil liberties; harm-reduction access is limited. This clashes with the family's pro-liberty values.
China offers tech startup subsidies in major cities. Incentives can help, but rents and salaries still push costs above global averages in Beijing/Shanghai.
China: Beijing/Shanghai costs high; Tier-2/3 cities offer affordable rents and schooling; with stable income, budgeting is manageable.
Beijing and Shanghai have many coworking spaces. For indie game teams, mocap/audio gear is scarce; expect basic shared options.
China has a large local dev pool, but visa limits for foreigners slow hiring; remote roles help mitigate, with friction in top cities.
In China, mental health care is expanding but access remains uneven. Stigma and provider gaps may affect your family's care in CN.
CN social depth grows slowly; in big cities English helps, but expat and gaming groups can help form close friendships over time.
D&I in China remains limited for LGBTQ+ and non-traditional families; urban tech hubs show some initiatives, but overall progress is modest.
China enforces drug laws strictly with heavy surveillance. Families may face unpredictable enforcement and higher penalties.
China does not recognize dual citizenship. To naturalize there, the US citizenship would typically need to be renounced.
In China, grants for foreigners are limited. Expect only small prototyping funds (~$5k–$25k).
China has mixed game funding: VCs, angels, incubators exist, but foreign founders face competition and regulatory hurdles; expect substantial effort.
China's large, growing economy shows resilient growth with occasional real estate/tech slumps; social buffers cushion family finances.
China's state-led market economy offers strong tech hubs and grants, but foreign founders face complex regulation and visa hurdles.
CN's tightly controlled policy and frequent tech/regulatory rules create planning uncertainty for tech/gaming ventures; shifts can be abrupt.
China has elite city schools for STEM, but gaokao pressure and centralized curricula curb progressive pedagogy. Bilingual programs exist mainly in big cities.
China has strong CS/game programs at top universities; big-city pipelines reliably feed local game talent.
CN: Sponsorship exists but quotas and paperwork can slow approvals; dependents possible, though process varies by city (Beijing/Shanghai).
China's Unity-dominated game dev scene, especially mobile. Unreal and other engines exist in studios, with cross-training resources available.
China's environment varies by city; air quality can trigger seasonal alerts and haze days. Urban parks offer relief and water quality is improving.
China (CN): taxes plus social contributions hover around 25–30%. Public services help justify the rate for families.
CN fall varies: Beijing 10–22 C. Shanghai 18–26 C, with typhoon season lingering on the SE coast.
In China’s cities, parks and schools exist. Childcare and tutoring require proactive organization; family life is workable.
CN allows spouses and minor children to join a primary visa holder (work/entrepreneur). Expect paperwork and possible delays.
China offers ~98 days maternity leave and universal healthcare; city-level childcare subsidies exist but access can be bureaucratic.
China's policy now allows more children (three-child era), but benefits are uneven; most costs rely on private funding with regional subsidies.
In China, visa families get limited public subsidies; most benefits rely on employer social insurance, with opaque rules and HR guidance often needed.
In China’s major cities, polished yet practical attire is common. Plan versatile, neat outfits for work and family days.
In China's urban centers, women's fashion is diverse and expressive. Workplaces often favor modest, formal attire.
Urban men's fashion in China centers on modern streetwear and smart-casual looks. Techwear influences are visible in big cities like Shanghai and Beijing.
In China (CN), femininity norms blend tradition with urban autonomy; women gain latitude but face appearance and family-role expectations.
China (CN) enforces strict gun laws with near-zero private ownership. Expect minimal exposure to firearms in public.
China (CN): consent norms vary; in large urban areas, mixed norms; proactively set boundaries in social/nightlife contexts.
China's startup hubs (Beijing/Shanghai) show a growing founder base with regular meetups. English-friendly groups exist, but local language helps integration.
Kansas City has solid fresh produce and a few international markets in key neighborhoods; we mix home cooking with occasional trips to specialty stores.
In China, locals are polite and connect when we take the initiative. Expect gradual bonding and reliance on expat and community groups.
China offers municipal game-dev grants for foreigners, but bureaucracy can be heavy; expect $50k-$125k/year.
China has a large mobile game market, with major studios in Shanghai/Beijing; content approvals slow; networking is essential for expats.
China (CN): gender diversity has limited legal recognition; social acceptance varies. Private support exists, but official protections are weak.
China has formal gender rights laws, but enforcement and pay equity vary by region. Urban areas show progress; rural areas lag.
Gender roles are largely egalitarian in Kansas City, Missouri; both adults work and share parenting. Some traditional expectations linger.
In urban China (CN), nontraditional flirting can face misinterpretation; expect cautious tolerance, gender scripts in nightlife, with limited LGBTQ visibility.
China visas are tied to work/category; expect renewals and PSB/registration. Internet controls and healthcare costs shape daily life.
China's coastal and river regions face stronger heat, floods; plan housing reinforcement and insurance; risk remains acceptable with mitigation.
China's startup visas are limited; most founders obtain work permits via corporate sponsorship, complicating family relocation.
CN urban centers favor neat, polished styles. Budget grooming time and outfits for Beijing or Shanghai.
In CN, multi-partner households face social stigma and legal barriers; discreet navigation is necessary.
China’s urban healthcare is decent with public insurance. Expect bureaucracy and some private options for smoother care.
China: Visa families rely on private international insurance; public hospital reimbursements are limited; expect higher out-of-pocket costs.
China offers broad public-university access for citizens; top programs are gaokao-competitive. Expats face higher tuition, with limited scholarships.
In China, international students can enroll in English-taught programs; scholarships exist, but tuition is high and visa steps add friction.
China's established studios hire at a moderate pace. Expect 3–4 months per role, with remote options for foreign applicants.
In China, foreign startup hires can take 6+ months due to visa rules; plan extended timelines; remote/hybrid options help.
China offers family-friendly housing in major cities, but expat searches can be competitive; expect higher deposits and longer search times.
In China, payroll is withheld with an annual settlement. Expats often need local tax advisors due to Mandarin forms.
CN sentiment is mixed; expats in megacities find communities and services, but face language gaps and bureaucratic hurdles. Proceed with caution.
In China, White migrants may face noticeable grumbles about costs and enclave living; engage locally to build trust and ease integration.
CN: For non-citizens, public K-12 is limited; enrollment hinges on hukou/residence; families often choose international/private schools despite higher cost.
Public K-12 for foreign families in China is limited; most use international/private schools; visa eligibility often dictates school choice.
CN: English usable in expat hubs (Shanghai/Shenzhen); Mandarin required for daily services; family plans to study Mandarin to participate.
In China, established studios use English for cross-border work; many teams operate bilingual (Chinese/English) for local compliance and partnerships.
China startups: English support mainly international-facing; Mandarin fluency is essential for hiring, compliance, and everyday ops.
China has solid IP firms with game IP experience; demand is high. Hire local counsel for IP, licensing, and publishing; English-friendly options exist.
CN: LGBTQ+ rights exist but social acceptance is uneven; public displays risk scrutiny; urban areas show stronger presence, but caution advised.
China has growing local playtest groups in major cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen); expect language coordination and some lead time.
Marxism informs policy in China. Public debate is limited and media is state-influenced.
China's urban contexts still lean traditional, but tech families push nontraditional roles; expect mild pushback yet progress.
In China (CN), mass violence is relatively infrequent; safety measures at schools and venues are common. Stay alert at large gatherings.
Tech meetups for expats exist in China but are regulated, making access irregular; we lean on online communities to connect.
China's minimum wage varies by city and often lags living costs in major metros. Two incomes or subsidies are commonly needed.
CN has strong urban infrastructure and fast internet; rural gaps exist. Ensure reliable broadband and low-latency access for work and gaming.
In China (CN), non-monogamy faces legal/social backlash; privacy and discretion vital for a progressive, poly-friendly family.
Open discussion in China can invite social penalties. Share concerns privately and respectfully to protect the family.
Spectacular landscapes in China (Guilin, Zhangjiajie); plenty of family-friendly parks and easy trails, though some sites charge fees or require longer drives.
China faces typhoons on the coast, floods, and inland earthquakes; for a family with young kids, plan evacuations and keep kid-friendly safety kits.
Nature access in China exists via urban parks, but bigger scenic trips require travel; air quality can affect outings near cities.
Beijing/Shanghai in CN host regular concerts and clubs; family-friendly venues exist, but late hours and language barriers require extra planning.
Nightlife in major Chinese cities (Beijing/Shanghai) exists in specific districts. For families, late options are limited; plan babysitters and safe transport.
China has government-backed game hubs and events in Beijing/Shanghai, but in-person meetups remain limited; families should rely on online game-dev communities and forums.
China hosts Tencent, NetEase, and miHoYo. A dense hub in Shanghai and Shenzhen with ChinaJoy boosting studio networking.
In CN (China), urban obesity is rising; parks and schools aid activity, but diet remains a challenge for our kids.
China offers strong dev talent and funding options. Game licenses and regulation slow launches, so startups need local partnerships.
CN pace varies by city. Big metros like Beijing/Shanghai are brisk, but inner-suburban CN towns offer slower routines; plan around traffic.
CN parenting norms push strong academic achievement; teachers and relatives may press for 'correct' methods, with high parental involvement.
In China, naturalization for foreigners is effectively unavailable; dual citizenship is not permitted, making citizenship unattainable for this family.
China shows moderate corruption perception; expect bureaucratic hurdles and careful navigation, despite ongoing anti-graft campaigns.
CN urban life is crowded; expect closer contact in trains/markets. Use gentle boundary cues to keep Trey, Sarah, and the kids comfortable.
China's crowded city life means closer contact in transit; politely cue for space. Handshakes common in business; hugs are rare.
In China, spring and autumn are pleasant in many cities; summers are hot and humid, winters cool, so outdoor plans require flexibility.
CN operates under a single-party system with centralized control; civil liberties are constrained, shaping visa options and migration plans.
China: polyamory carries legal and social risk; private multi-partner families face custody/housing challenges and limited acceptance.
CN has public and private preschools; access and fees vary by city with waitlists in districts. Bilingual options exist, but affordability is not universal.
China's major cities offer international/private schools (IB/AP); tuition is high and admissions are selective. Expat families find solid options in Beijing and Shanghai.
In urban China, clean eating is doable with planning. Convenience foods are always nearby, but fresh markets and healthier options exist.
China PMM (Games) pay trails top markets by ~25–30%; Shanghai/Beijing offer competitive packages with bonuses, but base salaries lag US levels.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: In China, continuing education for game product marketing is limited. Only occasional major-city conferences and online courses, with largely self-directed learning.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: China has many reputable marketing and game-design programs in major cities with industry ties. PMM curricula are growing, aided by studio partnerships.
CN PMM (Games) hiring typically 3–4 months; strong local game hubs exist, but visas/relocation slow onboarding. remote/hybrid options may help the family.
China game PMMs primarily use Mandarin; English usage is moderate and often requires screening. Bilingual Mandarin-English candidates fit well in Shanghai/Beijing studios.
In China, games marketing roles are largely onsite or hybrid; remote options exist case-by-case but with limited process maturity and timezone challenges.
China's games PMM pool is strong: many seasoned specialists across Tencent/NetEase studios and agencies; competition for top roles is noticeable.
China (CN): progressive activism is restricted; civil liberties are constrained, and feminist/LGBTQ+ advocacy faces state pushback.
In China, norms lean conservative; casual sex carries reputational risk. Urban areas show some openness, but overall acceptance remains limited.
China's public messaging is state-driven with limited independent media. The family values pluralistic sources and civil liberties.
In China, state media dominates and independent outlets are constrained; daily life is saturated with government messaging.
China's cities boast metro and high-speed rail; travel is efficient and family friendly, though health-code checks and real-name tickets add overhead.
China: limited direct BD access for foreign teams; rely on international conferences; pursue local partnerships to engage Chinese platforms.
China's Tier-1 cities offer abundant luxury dining, culture, and international schools; most services are accessible, though some niche options require early booking.
CN: A two-child expat family can manage on modest wages; healthcare and transit are solid, but expat schooling and housing in big cities can be tight.
CN middle-income families can access solid public services and good schools with mindful budgeting. Expat healthcare costs may strain budgets.
China offers strong real-time game pipelines (mobile/online) with pre-rendered work; good for cloud/remote teams, but regulatory barriers exist.
China: state atheism; religion tightly regulated; religion has limited policy influence, with personal freedoms constrained.
In China, established studios often allow remote on a case-by-case basis with a hybrid presence preferred, matching the family's need for flexibility.
In China, startups generally favor on-site work. Remote options exist mainly for senior roles.
China work culture is office-first; remote roles exist mainly in multinationals, with tax and logistics hurdles for home-based work.
China typically grants 1-year residence permits via Z visas; long-term residency is rare and mostly tied to investment or talent programs.
CN visa rules and Mandarin barriers may raise mid-term relocation risk; secure remote work and strong bilingual schooling to stay long-term.
China's urban pension exists with reforms; adequacy varies by city; healthcare remains supportive, though retirees often rely on savings.
In China, visa holders have limited access to the state pension; retirement relies on private savings; cross-border portability is limited.
Ruby is a niche skill in China (CN); few local roles exist, with remote work abroad as the main pathway.
China has low street crime; pervasive surveillance keeps incidents well-managed. Families can feel safe, with normal caution after dark in big cities.
CN offers expat-friendly international/private schools with English instruction and early childhood programs; public options are limited and waitlists long.
China's southern coast stays warm in summer; northern beaches cool outside peak months. Warm months are pleasant, but shoulder seasons may need light wetsuits for kids.
In China (CN), seasons are generally mild but summers can be hot and humid. Prepare versatile clothing and reliable climate control for year-round comfort.
In CN, winter days are ~9-10 hours and summers ~14-15 hours. Stay energized with outdoor breaks and light routines.
CN has distinct seasons: hot, humid summers and cold winters in many cities; plan for AC and winter gear, but outdoor activity is workable with prep.
CN has a strong senior tech bench in Beijing/Shanghai/Shenzhen; expect competitive offers, though expat visas can limit foreign-led senior hires.
In China (CN), sex education remains conservative with stigma; open discussions may invite censure and resources are limited.
China's social policies are evolving but uneven. Healthcare and welfare vary by province and are not fully universal.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: China's 2k sq ft rentals are tight in top metros; for a family of four, expect premium rents and broker help, with some competition and longer searches.
China spring varies by region: north drier with dust, south wetter. Most weeks hover around 12-23 C (54-73 F) with brief chilly rain.
China's governance is steady with predictable policy; dissent is managed. Economic stability supports long-term planning, though regulatory shifts occur.
In China, state ideology emphasizes centralized control and limited media pluralism. Dissent is restricted.
China's state-guided market economy blends growth with tight controls. For this family, policy shifts and local rules matter.
China has a dense game/animation studio scene, with hubs in Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen. It supports AAA and indie projects with ongoing studio formation.
CN summers are hot and humid (e.g., Shanghai 26–35 C). Humid stretches or 33–35 C peaks are common, yet pools and AC keep routines intact.
In China, service is efficient and polite but not chatty. English is less common outside expat hubs like Shanghai.
China (CN): incentives exist for games/creative sectors but are limited, with city-specific programs and competitive application windows.
China visa/residence for a US family can take up to a year; expect legal/translation fees and local admin steps.
In China, official trust may appear high, yet dissent is curtailed and civil-liberties constraints color daily life.
China's centralized oversight curbs major graft; local procurement issues exist but are addressed swiftly.
China tech salaries are solid but generally below US peaks. In Shenzhen/Shanghai, decent pay can cover local QoL, especially with remote work.
In China, weekends in major cities offer parks, museums, and family venues. Reservations are occasionally needed at popular spots, but plenty of spontaneous options remain.
CN schools run ~08:00–15:30/16:00; many offices 09:00–18:00; after-school care or paid help often needed for a 5-year-old; remote work helps.
China's statutory leave is often under 10 days (about 5 days for new hires). This can constrain family travel and caregiving.
Kansas City, USA typically offers about 20-24 vacation days. With family-friendly and remote-friendly firms, 25 days is achievable.
China offers a broad outsourcing ecosystem for art, QA, and engineering; ample capacity for overflow and live-ops. IP issues may affect pace and cost.
China: VFX Real-Time pay runs roughly 20% below global medians. Lower CN living costs offset part of the gap for families.
China hosts a growing real-time VFX scene with university programs and studios in major cities. Occasional workshops and active online communities exist.
China has several strong VFX/real-time degree programs (Beijing Film Academy, SJTU). These grads feed regional studios with solid portfolios annually.
CN real-time VFX roles in major hubs typically close in 1-2 months; strong local talent pools and improving English-friendly pipelines.
China: VFX (Real-Time) talent is partly English-speaking; many studios use Mandarin; bilingual candidates favored for international work.
China: remote options exist case-by-case for real-time VFX; mainly for senior or trusted contractors; many studios still favor onsite.
China's real-time VFX talent pool is large, with seasoned pros in Beijing/Shanghai across studios and outsourcing partners.
China's neighbors mix trade ties with border frictions (India, Vietnam); regional dynamics affect travel and daily life.
China: Proud of heritage and progress; wary of censorship. Seeks stable governance with room for open dialogue and civil liberties.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: China's neighbors in Asia view it with caution amid border and policy tensions; travel and trade for families can face friction.
China offers Z work visas with employer sponsorship and R talent visas for top hires; startup/entrepreneur routes are limited and competitive.
China's urban walkability varies; key neighborhoods have sidewalks and crossings. Drivers often rush, so stay vigilant with the kids.
In China (CN), US migrants face visa hurdles and occasional friction; expat hubs offer support, but travel and work permits are regulated.
China's blend of ancient culture and rapid modernization offers frequent learning moments. Cities like Shanghai and Beijing provide rich experiences for curious families.
CN winters vary: north around -5 to 5 C with occasional snow (Beijing); south milder (5-12 C); heating common and winters manageable.
In China (CN), 45-48 hour weeks are common in tech. Plan for flextime to protect family evenings.
In China, tech hours can be long. Seek remote/hybrid roles with clear boundaries to safeguard family time.
China's unions are state-controlled with limited protections; rights vary by region and enforcement is uneven; overall protections remain modest.
